entry.title: Recommend System Based on Bipartite Graph
entry.content:
Recommend Task

Given Data

Past user-item interactions, which are presented as bipartite graphs.

Task

Predict new items each user will interact in the future. Which can be cast as link prediction problemï¼Œin other words, predict new user-item interaction edges given the past edges.

We will compute the function f(u,v)f(u,v)f(u,v)ï¼Œin which u is user, v is item. fff shows the importance of edge (also the interaction). So if we can get all the scores of each pair of (ui,vi)(u_i,v_i)(uiâ€‹,viâ€‹) (include the edges appeared and have not appeared yet), we can easily give recommendations.

However, that cannot be implemented because of data scale. Commonly, we take 2 steps: Candidate generation (cheap, fast) and Ranking (slow, accurate).

As shown in the picture, use KNN to get 1000 candidates and compute the scores via f(u,v)f(u,v)f(u,v), then we get the top-k items for user. And K is typically range from 10 to 100. Our goal is to include as many positive items in these top-k items as possible.

Evaluation Method

How to evaluate the result? Use Recall@K method.

PuP_uPuâ€‹ are items that a user will interact in the future, RuR_uRuâ€‹ are items that recommended by model, it should be pointed out that items that the user has interacted before are excluded.

The final Recall@ğ¾ is computed by averaging the recall values across all users.

Score Function

To get the top-ğ¾ items, we need a score function for user-item interaction, then we choose the K items for user (exclude those items user interacted before)

Embedding-based Model

Embedding both uuu and vvv to RDR^DRD, and let score(u,v)â‰¡fÎ¸(u,v)score (u, v) \equiv{f_{ heta}{(\mathbf{u},\mathbf{v})}}score(u,v)â‰¡fÎ¸â€‹(u,v), which is a parameterized function. NOTE: the previous uï¼Œvuï¼Œvuï¼Œv represent user and itemï¼Œthe latter ones are embedding vectors of them.

So, there are actually 3 kinds of parameters will be optimizedï¼š

  • An encoder to generate item embeddings uuâˆˆUu_{u\in{U}}uuâˆˆUâ€‹
  • An encoder to generate item embeddings vvâˆˆVv_{v\in{V}}vvâˆˆVâ€‹
  • Score function fff

Our training object is make Recall@ğ¾ higher on seen user-item interactions, so that we can expect this would lead to high recall on future interactions (i.e. test dataset and real online situation).

Surrogate Losses

Surrogate losses are differentiable and should align well with the original training objective. We need surrogate loss because recall@K function is not differentiable. There are two popularity surrogate losses:

  • Binary loss
  • Bayesian Personalized Ranking (BPR) loss

Binary Loss Function

First, define positive edges and negative edges. Positive edges mean interactions are observed in dataset, while negative ones mean Eneg=(u,v)âˆ£(u,v)âˆ‰E,uâˆ‰U,vâˆ‰VE_{neg}={(u,v)\mid{(u, v) otin{E}},u otin U, v otin V}Enegâ€‹=(u,v)âˆ£(u,v)âˆˆ/E,uâˆˆ/U,vâˆˆ/V

Then we use sigmoidsigmoidsigmoid function to map real scores into binary scores (approximately).

Ïƒ(x)â‰¡11+eâˆ’x(1)\sigma{(x)} \equiv rac{1}{1+e^{-x}} ag{1}Ïƒ(x)â‰¡1+eâˆ’x1â€‹(1)

As formula (1) shows, if score is high, it is close to 1, otherwise close to 0.

Thus we can get the Binary Loss:

Ïƒ(fÎ¸(u,v))(2)\sigma{(f_{ heta}(u,v))} ag{2}Ïƒ(fÎ¸â€‹(u,v))(2)

Letâ€™s consider if a user has one positive edge to item 1 which scores 2, and one negative edge to item 2 which scores 2, too. When we compare the situation that once this model choose positive edge and negative edge respectively, we will find that if the loss function (2) get higher result in negative part otherwise positive part, the binary loss would still penalize the model prediction.

This lead to that optimizer will unnecessarily penalize model predictions even if the training recall metric is perfect (which means choose the positive edge, which is a successful recall).

So, letâ€™s consider the key sight of Binary Loss: The binary loss is non-personalized in the sense that the positive/negative edges are considered across ALL users at once. However, the recall metric is inherently personalized (defined for each user). The non-personalized binary loss is overly-stringent for the personalized recall metric.

As a result, this approach may not be optimal if the goal is to achieve high precision, which measures the proportion of positive predictions that are actually correct. The model may have high recall but low precision, which is not desirable in many practical applications.

In other words, we should compare the negative edge scores and positive scores in one person, not across users. Thatâ€™s because the score scale of different users ranges. For example, the value 2.0 of negative edge is a lower one on u1u_1u1â€‹, but higher than the positive edge value of 1.0 on u0u_0u0â€‹.

Bayesian Personalized Ranking (BPR) Loss

So, we get here! Because we now realize that surrogate loss function should be defined in a personalized manner. For each user, we want the scores of positive items to be higher than those of the negative items. We do not care about the score ordering across users.

For each user uâˆ—âˆˆUu^{*}\in{U}uâˆ—âˆˆU, we define the rooted positive edges and negative edges. Based on it, we want the scores of rooted positive edges E(uâˆ—)E(u^*)E(uâˆ—) to be higher than those of rooted negative edges Eneg(uâˆ—)E_{neg}(u^{*})Enegâ€‹(uâˆ—)

Then we compute the loss function of BPR:

Mini-batch training for the BPR loss means that compute the average of BPR loss over users in the mini-batch and update parameters (f,u,vf,\mathbf{u},\mathbf{v}f,u,v).

Summary So far

Why Embedding Methods Work well

The underlying idea: Collaborative filtering, which based on that similar users tend to prefer similar items. How to capture similarity between users/items? Embedding.

Embedding

Embedding mathematical definition: map an x into y, the structural characteristics of x can be maintained after mapping, this mapping is single injection and does not require full injection, how to better maintain the structure is a key point in machine learning

Embedding in Machine Learning:

  1. Narrow definition: the discrete, categorical data is projected into the vector space, such as the number of goods in the recommendation system is discrete, millions of numbers are independent of each other, then the final Embedding result is that each commodity is represented by a vector of hundreds of dimensions, since a vector of hundreds of dimensions can represent all goods, then the goods have been mapped to this hundreds of dimensional vector space, And the vectors in this space are continuous (linear embeddings), and the simplest way is one-hot encoding

  2. Generalized definition: feature processing, including manual feature engineering and NN-based representation learning

How Embedding Work

Low-dimensional embeddings cannot simply memorize all user-item interaction data. Embeddings are forced to capture similarity between users/items to fit the data. This allows the models to make effective prediction on unseen user-item interactions.

GNN for Recommend System

NGCFï¼šNeural Graph Collab. Filtering

Collaborative Filtering

A common approach to collaborative filtering is to use a matrix factorization model, which decomposes the user-item interaction matrix into two low-rank matrices representing user and item embeddings, respectively. These embeddings capture the latent features or attributes of users and items that are relevant for predicting their preferences.

Shallow Encoder

Conventional collaborative filtering model is based on shallow encoders, which means that traditional collaborative filtering models often use simple neural network architectures with few hidden layers to learn user and item embeddings. However, recent advancements in deep learning have led to the development of more complex and expressive deep collaborative filtering models.

The illustration of shallow encoders for embedding:

Limitations

  1. The model itself does not explicitly capture graph structure, it is only implicitly captured in the training objective.

  2. Only the first-order graph structure (i.e., edges) is captured in the training objective. High-order graph structure (e.g., ğ¾-hop paths between two nodes) is not explicitly captured.

Because the structure of shallow encoder is usually relatively simple, it cannot make good use of the multi-layer relationship between nodes and neighbors, which limits the performance of the model when dealing with higher-order graph structures.

Motivation of NGCF

We want a model thatï¼š

  1. explicitly captures graph structure (beyond implicitly through the training objective)
  2. captures high-order graph structure (beyond the first-order edge connectivity structure)

High-order connectivity:

GNNs are a natural approach to achieve bothï¼ŒNGCF explicitly incorporates high-order graph structure when generating user/item embeddings. The key idea is using a GNN to generate graph-aware user/item embeddings.

FrameWork

  1. Prepare shallow learnable embedding for each node.
  2. Use multi-layer GNNs to propagate embeddings on the bipartite graph
  3. Final embeddings are explicitly graph aware!

The structure of NGCF model:

This framework is joint learning: Shallow user/item embeddings and GNNâ€™s parameters are optimized simultaneously.

LightGCN

Motivation of LightGCN

NGCF jointly learns two kinds of parameters:

  1. Shallow user/item embeddings
  2. GNNâ€™s parameters

But, shallow learnable embeddings are already quite expressive, so the GNN parameters may not be so essential for performance. Thus we can simplify the GNN used in NGCF to reduce the number of parameters.

Shallow embedding result is like

Simplifying GCN

  1. Simplify GCN by removing ReLU non-linearity
  2. Multi-scale diffusion: (1) intra-layer neighborhood aggregation; (2) inter-layer combination.

Overview

First, initial learnable embedding matrix EEE

Notice: The normalization operation comes from GCN.

Second, iteratively diffuse embedding matrix EEE using A~ ilde{A}A~

Third, average the embedding matrices at different scales.

Fourth, use user/item vectors from EfinalE_{final}Efinalâ€‹ item interaction

Underlying Reason

Diffusion propagation only involves matrix-vector multiplication, and the simplification leads to better empirical performance than NGCF. The simple diffusion propagation work well may depends on:

The diffusion directly encourages the embeddings of similar users/items to be similar. Similar users share many common neighbors (items) and are expected to have similar future preferences (interact with similar items).

Reference

  1. LightGCN for Movie Recommendation | by Quinn Wang | Stanford CS224W GraphML Tutorials | Medium

  2. CS224W | Home

  3. embedding & representation learning - Bilibili

  4. NGCF paper

å…¶ä¸­ï¼ŒCiC_iCiâ€‹ è¡¨ç¤ºç¬¬ iii ä¸ªèŠ‚ç‚¹çš„èšç±»ç³»æ•°ï¼ŒEiE_iEiâ€‹ è¡¨ç¤ºç¬¬ iii ä¸ªèŠ‚ç‚¹é‚»å±…èŠ‚ç‚¹ä¹‹é—´å½¢æˆè¿æ¥çš„æ•°é‡ï¼Œkik_ikiâ€‹ è¡¨ç¤ºç¬¬ iii ä¸ªèŠ‚ç‚¹çš„åº¦æ•°ï¼ˆå³ä¸è¯¥èŠ‚ç‚¹ç›¸è¿çš„è¾¹æ•°ï¼‰ã€‚éœ€è¦æ³¨æ„çš„æ˜¯ï¼Œåœ¨è®¡ç®—èšç±»ç³»æ•°æ—¶ï¼Œå¯¹äºåº¦æ•°å°äºç­‰äº 1 çš„èŠ‚ç‚¹ï¼Œå…¶èšç±»ç³»æ•°å®šä¹‰ä¸º 0ã€‚

Graphlet

è‡³äº random walk çš„æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œæ˜¯å¯é€‰æ‹©çš„ç­–ç•¥ï¼Œæ‹¿åˆ° embedding çš„ç»“æœï¼Œè®¡ç®—ç›¸ä¼¼åº¦ï¼Œæ ¹æ®ç›¸ä¼¼åº¦è¿›è¡Œä¼˜åŒ–ï¼Œä¼˜åŒ–å¾—æ–¹æ³•ä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥é€‰æ‹©æ¢¯åº¦ä¸‹é™ä¹‹ç±»çš„

Sampling anonymous walks æ˜¯ä¸€ç§åœ¨å›¾ä¸Šè¿›è¡Œé‡‡æ ·çš„æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œä¸»è¦äºç”Ÿæˆæ— æ ‡ç­¾çš„éšæœºæ¸¸èµ°åºåˆ—ã€‚æ— æ ‡ç­¾çš„éšæœºæ¸¸èµ°åºåˆ—æŒ‡çš„æ˜¯åœ¨æ¸¸èµ°è¿‡ç¨‹ä¸­ä¸è®°å½•èŠ‚ç‚¹çš„æ ‡ç­¾ä¿¡æ¯ï¼Œåªè®°å½•èŠ‚ç‚¹çš„é¡ºåºä¿¡æ¯ï¼Œå› æ­¤ä¹Ÿè¢«ç§°ä¸ºåŒ¿åæ¸¸èµ°åºåˆ—ã€‚

è¿™ç§é‡‡æ ·æ–¹æ³•æ˜¯åŸºäºéšæœºæ¸¸èµ°çš„æ€æƒ³ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­éšæœºæ¸¸èµ°æ˜¯æŒ‡ä»å›¾ä¸­çš„æŸä¸ªèŠ‚ç‚¹å¼€å§‹ï¼Œä»¥ä¸€å®šçš„æ¦‚ç‡è§„åˆ™æ­¥è¿›åˆ°ä¸‹ä¸€ä¸ªèŠ‚ç‚¹ï¼Œå¹¶åœ¨ä¸€å®šæ­¥æ•°åç»ˆæ­¢æ¸¸èµ°ã€‚Sampling anonymous walks æ–¹æ³•å°†éšæœºæ¸¸èµ°çš„è¿‡ç¨‹è¿›è¡Œæ‰©å±•ï¼Œé€šè¿‡å¤šæ¬¡ç‹¬ç«‹çš„éšæœºæ¸¸èµ°ï¼Œè®°å½•æ‰€æœ‰çš„åŒ¿åæ¸¸èµ°åºåˆ—ï¼Œä»¥æ›´åŠ å…¨é¢åœ°åˆ»ç”»å›¾çš„ç»“æ„ä¿¡æ¯ã€‚

Sampling anonymity walks æ–¹æ³•å¯ä»¥å¸®åŠ©æˆ‘ä»¬æå–èŠ‚ç‚¹åºåˆ—ç‰¹å¾ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚åœ¨èŠ‚ç‚¹åµŒå…¥ä¸­ä½¿ç”¨ï¼Œä»¥ä¾¿æ›´å¥½åœ°å¯¹èŠ‚ç‚¹è¿›è¡Œèšç±»ã€åˆ†ç±»ã€é¢„æµ‹ç­‰ä»»åŠ¡ã€‚æ­¤å¤–ï¼Œç”±äºä¸è®°å½•èŠ‚ç‚¹æ ‡ç­¾ä¿¡æ¯ï¼Œå› æ­¤è¯¥æ–¹æ³•å¯ä»¥æ¶ˆé™¤èŠ‚ç‚¹æ ‡ç­¾åå·®çš„å½±å“ï¼Œé™ä½äº†èŠ‚ç‚¹æ ‡ç­¾ä¿¡æ¯çš„è¦æ±‚ã€‚

Node2Vec

Node2Vec æ˜¯ä¸€ç§å›¾åµŒå…¥ç®—æ³•ï¼Œç”¨äºå°†å›¾ä¸­çš„èŠ‚ç‚¹åµŒå…¥åˆ°ä½ç»´å‘é‡ç©ºé—´ä¸­ã€‚å®ƒæ˜¯åœ¨ DeepWalk ç®—æ³•çš„åŸºç¡€ä¸Šå‘å±•è€Œæ¥çš„ã€‚Node2Vec çš„æ€æƒ³æ˜¯ï¼Œå°†å›¾ä¸­çš„èŠ‚ç‚¹åˆ†æˆä¸åŒçš„ç±»å‹ï¼Œæ¯ç§ç±»å‹çš„èŠ‚ç‚¹å…·æœ‰ä¸åŒçš„è¯­ä¹‰è¡¨ç¤ºã€‚ç„¶ååœ¨è¿™ç§è¡¨ç¤ºä¸‹ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨éšæœºæ¸¸èµ°é‡‡æ ·æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œç”ŸæˆèŠ‚ç‚¹åºåˆ—ï¼Œå¹¶åœ¨æ­¤åŸºç¡€ä¸Šè¿›è¡Œæ¨¡å‹è®­ç»ƒï¼Œå¾—åˆ°æ¯ä¸ªèŠ‚ç‚¹çš„é«˜è´¨é‡åµŒå…¥å‘é‡ã€‚

Node2Vec é€šè¿‡è°ƒæ•´èŠ‚ç‚¹é—´æ¸¸èµ°çš„æ¦‚ç‡åˆ†å¸ƒï¼Œå°†èŠ‚ç‚¹çš„è¯­ä¹‰è½¬åŒ–ä¸ºå‘é‡è¡¨ç¤ºï¼Œä»è€Œå°†å›¾ç»“æ„è½¬åŒ–ä¸ºå‘é‡ç©ºé—´ä¸­çš„å‡ ä½•ç»“æ„ã€‚å…·ä½“æ¥è¯´ï¼ŒNode2Vec ä¸ºæ¯ä¸ªèŠ‚ç‚¹å®šä¹‰äº†ä¸¤ä¸ªå‚æ•° p å’Œ qï¼Œç”¨äºæ§åˆ¶æ¸¸èµ°çš„è¿‡ç¨‹ã€‚å‚æ•° p æ§åˆ¶ç›´æ¥è·³è½¬åˆ°é‚»å±…èŠ‚ç‚¹çš„æ¦‚ç‡ï¼Œå‚æ•° q æ§åˆ¶å‘è¾ƒè¿œèŠ‚ç‚¹è·³è½¬çš„æ¦‚ç‡ã€‚é€šè¿‡è°ƒæ•´è¿™ä¸¤ä¸ªå‚æ•°ï¼ŒNode2Vec èƒ½å¤Ÿåœ¨ " æ·±å…¥ " æˆ– " å¹¿åº¦ä¼˜å…ˆ " ä¹‹é—´åˆ‡æ¢ï¼Œè¿™ä½¿å¾—å®ƒèƒ½å¤Ÿæ›´å¥½åœ°æ•æ‰èŠ‚ç‚¹ä¹‹é—´çš„ä¸åŒç‰¹å¾ã€‚

Summary So far

Core idea: Embed nodes so that distances in embedding space reflect node similarities in the original network.

Different notions of node similarity:

  • Naive: Similar if two nodes are connected (next)
  • Neighborhood overlap (covered in Lecture 2)
  • Random walk approaches (covered today)

In general: Must choose definition of node similarity that matches our application.

Graph Embedding

Node embedding çš„ç›®æ ‡æ˜¯å°†å•ä¸ªèŠ‚ç‚¹åµŒå…¥åˆ°ä½ç»´å‘é‡ç©ºé—´ä¸­ã€‚ä¸ Graph embedding ç®—æ³•ä¸åŒï¼ŒNode embedding ç®—æ³•é€šå¸¸ä»èŠ‚ç‚¹çš„å±€éƒ¨ç»“æ„å’Œé‚»å±…èŠ‚ç‚¹ä¿¡æ¯å‡ºå‘ï¼ŒæŠŠèŠ‚ç‚¹å‘¨å›´çš„ç»“æ„å’Œå±æ€§ä¿¡æ¯è€ƒè™‘åœ¨å†…ï¼Œå¯¹å•ä¸ªèŠ‚ç‚¹è¿›è¡ŒåµŒå…¥ã€‚å¸¸ç”¨çš„ Node embedding ç®—æ³•åŒ…æ‹¬ DeepWalkã€node2vecã€LINEã€Struc2Vec ç­‰ã€‚Node embedding é€‚ç”¨äºåº”å¯¹ç‰¹å®šèŠ‚ç‚¹çš„å±æ€§é¢„æµ‹ã€èŠ‚ç‚¹æ¨èç­‰ä»»åŠ¡ã€‚

ç›¸æ¯”ä¹‹ä¸‹ï¼ŒGraph embedding çš„ç›®æ ‡æ˜¯å°†æ•´ä¸ªå›¾ç»“æ„åµŒå…¥åˆ°ä½ç»´å‘é‡ç©ºé—´ä¸­ã€‚Graph embedding ç®—æ³•é€šå¸¸ä»æ•´ä¸ªå›¾çš„å…¨å±€ç»“æ„å‡ºå‘ï¼Œå°†å›¾ä¸­èŠ‚ç‚¹å’Œè¾¹çš„å…³ç³»ä»¥åŠå…¶ä»–å›¾å±æ€§è€ƒè™‘åœ¨å†…ï¼Œå¯¹æ•´ä¸ªå›¾ç»“æ„è¿›è¡ŒåµŒå…¥ã€‚å¸¸ç”¨çš„ Graph embedding ç®—æ³•åŒ…æ‹¬ DeepWalkã€node2vecã€LINEã€SDNE ç­‰ã€‚Graph embedding é€‚ç”¨äºåº”å¯¹å…¨å±€ç»Ÿè®¡å’Œç»“æ„åˆ†æçš„é—®é¢˜ï¼Œå¯ä»¥ç”¨äºå›¾åˆ†ç±»ã€èšç±»ã€å¯è§†åŒ–ç­‰ä»»åŠ¡ã€‚

ä½¿ç”¨ gradle init å‘½ä»¤å¯ä»¥å¿«é€Ÿåˆ›å»ºä¸€ä¸ªåŸºæœ¬çš„ Gradle é¡¹ç›®ç»“æ„ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯æˆ‘ä»¬ä»ç„¶éœ€è¦è‡ªå·±ç¼–å†™é…ç½®æ–‡ä»¶æ¥æŒ‡å®šé¡¹ç›®çš„ä¾èµ–é¡¹å’Œå…¶ä»–é…ç½®ã€‚

åœ¨ä¸€ä¸ªå¤šæ¨¡å—çš„ Gradle é¡¹ç›®ä¸­ï¼Œsettings.gradle æ–‡ä»¶ç”¨äºæŒ‡å®šå­é¡¹ç›®å’Œå®ƒä»¬çš„è·¯å¾„ã€‚å­é¡¹ç›®å¯ä»¥åˆ†åˆ«æ˜¯ Java åº”ç”¨ã€åº“æ¨¡å—ã€æ’ä»¶æ¨¡å—ã€web åº”ç”¨ç­‰ã€‚æ‚¨å¯ä»¥åœ¨ settings.gradle æ–‡ä»¶ä¸­å®šä¹‰å­é¡¹ç›®åç§°å’Œè·¯å¾„ï¼Œä»¥ä¾¿ Gradle å¯ä»¥æ‰¾åˆ°å®ƒä»¬å¹¶åœ¨æ„å»ºè¿‡ç¨‹ä¸­å¤„ç†å®ƒä»¬ã€‚ä¾‹å¦‚ï¼š

Computational Graph

Gradient

æ ¹æ®åå¯¼æ•°å®šä¹‰ï¼Œå‡½æ•°å€¼çš„å˜åŒ–è¿‘ä¼¼æ˜¯ï¼š

Î”f=âˆ‚fâˆ‚w1Î”w1+âˆ‚fâˆ‚w2Î”w2(1)\Delta{f}=\frac{\partial{f}}{\partial{w_1}}\Delta{w_1}+\frac{\partial{f}}{\partial{w_2}}\Delta{w_2}\tag{1}Î”f=âˆ‚w1â€‹âˆ‚fâ€‹Î”w1â€‹+âˆ‚w2â€‹âˆ‚fâ€‹Î”w2â€‹(1)

Î”fâˆ£Î”wâˆ£=âˆ‚fâˆ‚w1Î”w1+âˆ‚fâˆ‚w2Î”w2(Î”w1)2+Î”w2)2=(âˆ‚fâˆ‚w1,âˆ‚fâˆ‚w2)(Î”w1(Î”w1)2+Î”w2)2Î”w1(Î”w1)2+Î”w2)2)(3)\frac{\Delta{f}}{\mid{\Delta{w}}\mid}=\frac{\frac{\partial{f}}{\partial{w_1}}\Delta{w_1}+\frac{\partial{f}}{\partial{w_2}}\Delta{w_2}}{\sqrt{({\Delta{w_1}})^2+{\Delta{w_2}})^2}}=(\frac{\partial{f}}{\partial{w_1}},\frac{\partial{f}}{\partial{w_2}})\begin{pmatrix} \frac{\Delta{w_1}}{\sqrt{({\Delta{w_1}})^2+{\Delta{w_2}})^2}} \\\frac{\Delta{w_1}}{\sqrt{({\Delta{w_1}})^2+{\Delta{w_2}})^2}}\end{pmatrix}\tag{3}âˆ£Î”wâˆ£Î”fâ€‹=(Î”w1â€‹)2+Î”w2â€‹)2â€‹âˆ‚w1â€‹âˆ‚fâ€‹Î”w1â€‹+âˆ‚w2â€‹âˆ‚fâ€‹Î”w2â€‹â€‹=(âˆ‚w1â€‹âˆ‚fâ€‹,âˆ‚w2â€‹âˆ‚fâ€‹)â€‹(Î”w1â€‹)2+Î”w2â€‹)2â€‹Î”w1â€‹â€‹(Î”w1â€‹)2+Î”w2â€‹)2â€‹Î”w1â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹(3)

å…¶ä¸­æ¢¯åº¦æ˜¯ï¼š

(âˆ‚fâˆ‚w1,âˆ‚fâˆ‚w2)(4)(\frac{\partial{f}}{\partial{w_1}},\frac{\partial{f}}{\partial{w_2}})\tag{4}(âˆ‚w1â€‹âˆ‚fâ€‹,âˆ‚w2â€‹âˆ‚fâ€‹)(4)

ä½ç§»å‘é‡æ‰€æŒ‡æ–¹å‘çš„å•ä½å‘é‡ï¼š

(Î”w1(Î”w1)2+Î”w2)2Î”w1(Î”w1)2+Î”w2)2)(5)\begin{pmatrix} \frac{\Delta{w_1}}{\sqrt{({\Delta{w_1}})^2+{\Delta{w_2}})^2}} \\\frac{\Delta{w_1}}{\sqrt{({\Delta{w_1}})^2+{\Delta{w_2}})^2}}\end{pmatrix}\tag{5}â€‹(Î”w1â€‹)2+Î”w2â€‹)2â€‹Î”w1â€‹â€‹(Î”w1â€‹)2+Î”w2â€‹)2â€‹Î”w1â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹(5)

æ‰€ä»¥ï¼Œæœ‰ä»¥ä¸‹ç»“è®ºï¼š

  1. å‡½æ•°åœ¨ www å¤„æ²¿ç€æŸæ–¹å‘ Î”w\Delta{w}Î”w çš„æ–¹å‘å¯¼æ•°æ˜¯å‡½æ•°åœ¨ www å¤„çš„æ¢¯åº¦å’Œä½ç§»æ–¹å‘çš„å•ä½å‘é‡çš„å†…ç§¯ï¼Œä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥è¯´æ–¹å‘å¯¼æ•°ç­‰äºæ¢¯åº¦å‘è¯¥æ–¹å‘çš„æŠ•å½±
  2. ä¸Šä¸€æ¡ä¹Ÿç­‰ä»·äºï¼šæ–¹å‘å¯¼æ•°æ˜¯æ¢¯åº¦åœ¨è¯¥æ–¹å‘çš„æŠ•å½±
  3. æ–¹å‘å¯¼æ•°æ˜¯å‡½æ•°æ²¿ç€å„ä¸ªæ–¹å‘çš„å¯¼æ•°ï¼Œæ¢¯åº¦æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªå‘é‡ï¼Œå› æ­¤æ¢¯åº¦æœ¬èº«æœ‰æ–¹å‘
  4. ä¸€ä¸ªå‡½æ•°åœ¨å„ä¸ªæ–¹å‘éƒ½æœ‰å¯¼æ•°ï¼Œä½†å‡½æ•°åœ¨æ¢¯åº¦æ–¹å‘çš„æ–¹å‘å¯¼æ•°æ˜¯æœ€å¤§çš„
  5. å‡½æ•°æ–¹å‘å¯¼æ•°çš„æœ€å¤§å€¼ä¸ºæ¢¯åº¦çš„æ¨¡
  6. å‚ç›´äºæ¢¯åº¦æ–¹å‘çš„å¯¼æ•°ä¸º 0

è¿™é‡Œæœ‰ä¸ªç‚¹è¦æ³¨æ„ï¼Œè™½ç„¶åœ¨å¼å­ï¼ˆ3ï¼‰ä¸­æˆ‘ä»¬æ˜¯æ‹¿åˆ°ä½ç§» Î”w\Delta{w}Î”w åæ‰æ¨å‡ºçš„æ²¿ç€è¿åŠ¨æ–¹å‘çš„åå¯¼æ•°ä»¥åŠæ¢¯åº¦ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯å®é™…ä¸Šè¿™ä¸ªå®šä¹‰å¹¶ä¸éœ€è¦ä½ç§» Î”w\Delta{w}Î”wï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥å‡½æ•°ç¡®å®šäº†åæ ‡ç³»çš„ä¸€ä¸ªç‚¹ä¹‹åï¼Œåœ¨è¯¥ç‚¹çš„æ¢¯åº¦å‘é‡æ˜¯ç¡®å®šçš„ï¼Œè‡³äºç¬¬ 5 æ¡ï¼Œå½“ä½ç§»å‘é‡å’Œæ¢¯åº¦å‘é‡é‡åˆæ—¶ï¼Œè¯¥ç‚¹ç§¯å€¼ç­‰äºæ¢¯åº¦çš„æ¨¡ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥æ­¤æ—¶æ–¹å‘å¯¼æ•°å–å¾—æœ€å¤§å€¼ã€‚

Chain Rule and back Propagation

Vector Function and Jacobi Matrix

å¯ä»¥å°†ä¸€ä¸ªç»“ç‚¹çœ‹åšä¸€ä¸ªæ˜ å°„å…³ç³»ï¼Œä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªå‡½æ•°ï¼Œå¯¹äºä¸€ä¸ªå†…ç§¯ç»“ç‚¹è€Œè¨€ï¼Œå…¶è¾“å…¥æ—¶ä¸€ä¸ªè¡Œå‘é‡ www å’Œä¸€ä¸ªåˆ—å‘é‡ xxxï¼Œç„¶åè¯¥å†…ç§¯æ˜ å°„æ±‚å¾—å†…ç§¯ç»“æœä¸ºä¸€ä¸ªå¸¸æ•°ã€‚

è®¡ç®—å›¾ä¸­çš„æ¯ä¸ª operator èŠ‚ç‚¹éƒ½æ˜¯å¤šåˆ°å¤šï¼ˆå‘é‡åˆ°å‘é‡ï¼Œå¸¸é‡å¯ä»¥çœ‹åšæ˜¯ä¸€ç»´å‘é‡ï¼ŒçŸ©é˜µå¯ä»¥çœ‹æˆå¤šä¸ªå‘é‡ï¼‰çš„æ˜ å°„ã€‚

æ ‡é‡å‡½æ•°æ˜¯ä»€ä¹ˆæ ·çš„ï¼Ÿå¤šä¸ªè¾“å…¥å€¼è®¡ç®—å‡ºä¸€ä¸ªå€¼ã€‚è€Œå‘é‡å‡½æ•°å°±æ˜¯è¾“å…¥å’Œè¾“å‡ºéƒ½æ˜¯å‘é‡çš„å‡½æ•°ï¼Œä¸€ä¸ª nnn ç»´å‘é‡ www è®¡ç®—å¾—åˆ° mmm ç»´å‘é‡çš„æ˜ å°„å¯ä»¥çœ‹åšæ˜¯ mmm ä¸ªæ ‡é‡å‡½æ•°å¯¹è¿™ä¸ª nnn ç»´å‘é‡éƒ½å¤„ç†äº†ä¸€æ¬¡ï¼Œä¸”å¤„ç†ä¸€æ¬¡å³æŠŠè¯¥ nnn ç»´å‘é‡çš„æ‰€æœ‰ç»´åº¦éƒ½å¤„ç†äº†ï¼š

f(w)=(f1(w)f2(w)â‹¯fm(w))(6)f(w)=\begin{pmatrix}f_1{(w)} \\f_2{(w)} \\\cdots \\f_m{(w)}\end{pmatrix}\tag{6}f(w)=â€‹f1â€‹(w)f2â€‹(w)â‹¯fmâ€‹(w)â€‹â€‹(6)

å¯¹äºä»»æ„ fi(w)f_i(w)fiâ€‹(w) è€Œè¨€ï¼Œå®ƒæ˜¾ç„¶æ˜¯ä¸ªæ ‡é‡å‡½æ•°ï¼Œè¾“å…¥å€¼ä¸º nnn ç»´å‘é‡ï¼Œè¾“å‡ºä¸ºæ ‡é‡

è€Œæ ‡é‡å‡½æ•°æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥è®¡ç®—å®ƒçš„æ¢¯åº¦ä¸ºï¼š

(âˆ‚(f1)(w1)(w)â‹¯âˆ‚(f1)(w1)(w))(7)\begin{pmatrix} \frac{\partial(f_1)}{(w_1)}(w)\cdots\frac{\partial(f_1)}{(w_1)}(w)\end{pmatrix}\tag{7}((w1â€‹)âˆ‚(f1â€‹)â€‹(w)â‹¯(w1â€‹)âˆ‚(f1â€‹)â€‹(w)â€‹)(7)

æ ¹æ®æŸå¤±å‡½æ•°è®¡ç®—å‚æ•°çš„æ¢¯åº¦ï¼Œé¦–å…ˆçœ‹ losslossloss å¯¹ b2b_2b2â€‹ è¿™ä¸ªå¸¸æ•°çš„æ¢¯åº¦ï¼Œlosslossloss å¯¹å…¶æ±‚å¯¼ç»“æœæ˜¯ âˆ’(yâ‹…(1âˆ’a2)âˆ’(1âˆ’y)â‹…a2)- (y \cdot (1 - a2) - (1 - y) \cdot a2)âˆ’(yâ‹…(1âˆ’a2)âˆ’(1âˆ’y)â‹…a2)ï¼Œæ¨å¯¼è¿‡ç¨‹å¦‚ä¸‹ (ä¸‹é¢ç®€ç§° losslossloss ä¸º LLL)ï¼š

âˆ‚Lâˆ‚b2=âˆ‚Lâˆ‚a2â‹…âˆ‚a2âˆ‚b2=âˆ’(ya2âˆ’(1âˆ’y)â‹…11âˆ’a2)â‹…âˆ‚a2âˆ‚b2=âˆ’(ya2âˆ’(1âˆ’y)â‹…11âˆ’a2)â‹…a2(1âˆ’a2)=âˆ’(yâ‹…(1âˆ’a2)âˆ’(1âˆ’y)â‹…a2)(15)\begin{equation}\begin{split}\frac{\partial{L}}{\partial{b_2}} = & \frac{\partial{L}}{\partial{a_2}}\cdot \frac{\partial{a_2}}{\partial{b_2}} \\= & -(\frac{y}{a_2}-(1-y)\cdot{\frac{1}{1-a_2}})\cdot \frac{\partial{a_2}}{\partial{b_2}} \\= & -(\frac{y}{a_2}-(1-y)\cdot{\frac{1}{1-a_2}})\cdot{a_2}(1-a_2) \\= & -(y\cdot(1-a_2)-(1-y)\cdot{a_2})\end{split}\end{equation}\tag{15}âˆ‚b2â€‹âˆ‚Lâ€‹====â€‹âˆ‚a2â€‹âˆ‚Lâ€‹â‹…âˆ‚b2â€‹âˆ‚a2â€‹â€‹âˆ’(a2â€‹yâ€‹âˆ’(1âˆ’y)â‹…1âˆ’a2â€‹1â€‹)â‹…âˆ‚b2â€‹âˆ‚a2â€‹â€‹âˆ’(a2â€‹yâ€‹âˆ’(1âˆ’y)â‹…1âˆ’a2â€‹1â€‹)â‹…a2â€‹(1âˆ’a2â€‹)âˆ’(yâ‹…(1âˆ’a2â€‹)âˆ’(1âˆ’y)â‹…a2â€‹)â€‹â€‹(15)

å…¶ä¸­ a2=sigmoid(w2â‹…a1+b2)a_2=sigmoid(w_2\cdot{a_1} + b_2)a2â€‹=sigmoid(w2â€‹â‹…a1â€‹+b2â€‹)ï¼Œå†åˆ©ç”¨é“¾å¼æ±‚å¯¼å’Œå¼ 12 ï¼Œ âˆ‚a2âˆ‚b2\frac{\partial{a_2}}{\partial{b_2}}âˆ‚b2â€‹âˆ‚a2â€‹â€‹ çš„ç»“æœæ˜¯ï¼š

âˆ‚a2âˆ‚b2=âˆ‚(sigmoid(w2â‹…a1+b))âˆ‚(w2â‹…a1+b)â‹…âˆ‚(w2â‹…a1+b)âˆ‚b=a2â‹…(1âˆ’a2)(16)\begin{equation}\begin{split}\frac{\partial{a_2}}{\partial{b_2}}=&\frac{\partial{(sigmoid(w_2\cdot{a_1}+b))}}{\partial{(w_2\cdot{a_1}+b)}}\cdot\frac{\partial(w_2\cdot{a_1}+b)}{\partial{b}} \\=& a_2\cdot(1-a_2)\end{split}\end{equation}\tag{16}âˆ‚b2â€‹âˆ‚a2â€‹â€‹==â€‹âˆ‚(w2â€‹â‹…a1â€‹+b)âˆ‚(sigmoid(w2â€‹â‹…a1â€‹+b))â€‹â‹…âˆ‚bâˆ‚(w2â€‹â‹…a1â€‹+b)â€‹a2â€‹â‹…(1âˆ’a2â€‹)â€‹â€‹(16)

ç±»ä¼¼çš„ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥ä¾æ¬¡è®¡ç®— losslossloss å¯¹ w2w_2w2â€‹ ã€b1b_1b1â€‹ã€w1w_1w1â€‹ çš„å¯¼æ•°ï¼Œä¸‹é¢ä»…ä¸¾ä¾‹ï¼š

âˆ‚Lâˆ‚w2=âˆ‚Lâˆ‚a2â‹…âˆ‚a2âˆ‚w2=âˆ’(ya2âˆ’(1âˆ’y)â‹…11âˆ’a2)â‹…âˆ‚a2âˆ‚w2=âˆ’(ya2âˆ’(1âˆ’y)â‹…11âˆ’a2)â‹…a2(1âˆ’a2)â‹…x2=âˆ’(yâ‹…(1âˆ’a2)âˆ’(1âˆ’y)â‹…a2)â‹…x2=âˆ‚Lâˆ‚b2â‹…x2(16)\begin{equation}\begin{split}\frac{\partial{L}}{\partial{w_2}} = & \frac{\partial{L}}{\partial{a_2}}\cdot \frac{\partial{a_2}}{\partial{w_2}} \\= & -(\frac{y}{a_2}-(1-y)\cdot{\frac{1}{1-a_2}})\cdot \frac{\partial{a_2}}{\partial{w_2}} \\= & -(\frac{y}{a_2}-(1-y)\cdot{\frac{1}{1-a_2}})\cdot{a_2}(1-a_2)\cdot {x_2} \\= & -(y\cdot(1-a_2)-(1-y)\cdot{a_2})\cdot{x_2} \\= & \frac{\partial{L}}{\partial{b_2}} \cdot {x_2}\end{split}\end{equation}\tag{16}âˆ‚w2â€‹âˆ‚Lâ€‹=====â€‹âˆ‚a2â€‹âˆ‚Lâ€‹â‹…âˆ‚w2â€‹âˆ‚a2â€‹â€‹âˆ’(a2â€‹yâ€‹âˆ’(1âˆ’y)â‹…1âˆ’a2â€‹1â€‹)â‹…âˆ‚w2â€‹âˆ‚a2â€‹â€‹âˆ’(a2â€‹yâ€‹âˆ’(1âˆ’y)â‹…1âˆ’a2â€‹1â€‹)â‹…a2â€‹(1âˆ’a2â€‹)â‹…x2â€‹âˆ’(yâ‹…(1âˆ’a2â€‹)âˆ’(1âˆ’y)â‹…a2â€‹)â‹…x2â€‹âˆ‚b2â€‹âˆ‚Lâ€‹â‹…x2â€‹â€‹â€‹(16)

æ³¨æ„ï¼Œæ±‚å¯¼ç»“æœè¿˜è¦è¿›è¡ŒçŸ©é˜µè½¬ç§©åï¼Œæ‰èƒ½ç”¨äºæ›´æ–° w2w_2w2â€‹

æœ€åï¼Œå…³äºæ¢¯åº¦å¹³å‡çš„é—®é¢˜ï¼Œæ¯æ¬¡ backward æ‰§è¡Œåè®¡ç®—åˆ°çš„æ¢¯åº¦æ˜¯å¹³å‡å€¼ã€‚æ€»å…±æ•°æ® x æœ‰ 4 ç»„æ•°æ®ï¼Œæ¯ä¸ª epoch å°†å››ç»„æ•°æ®éƒ½è®¡ç®—ä¸€éæ¢¯åº¦å€¼ï¼Œå†é™¤ä»¥ 4 å¾—åˆ°çš„æ˜¯è¯¥ epoch ä¸‹çš„åå‘ä¼ æ’­æ¢¯åº¦å€¼ï¼Œç”¨è¿™ä¸ªå¹³å‡æ¢¯åº¦å€¼å»æ›´æ–°å‚æ•°ï¼Œè¿™æ„å‘³ç€è¿™é‡Œä½¿ç”¨çš„æ˜¯å…¨æ‰¹é‡æ¢¯åº¦ä¸‹é™æ³•ã€‚å¦å¤–ï¼Œæ¯ä¸ª epoch ä¸­è®¡ç®—çš„ 4 ä¸ªæ¢¯åº¦æ˜¯ç´¯åŠ ï¼Œè€Œæ›´æ–°æ—¶ä½¿ç”¨å‡æ³•ï¼Œæ¯•ç«Ÿæ˜¯æ¢¯åº¦ä¸‹é™è€Œä¸æ˜¯æ¢¯åº¦ä¸Šå‡ï¼Œè¿™ç¬¦åˆæˆ‘ä»¬æœ€å°åŒ– losslossloss å‡½æ•°çš„ç›®æ ‡ã€‚

å…·ä½“ä»£ç å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼š

ç»¼ä¸Šï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°†è®­ç»ƒæ•°æ®é€è‡³ backward å‡½æ•°å³å¯è°ƒç”¨åå‘ä¼ æ’­çš„è®¡ç®—è¿‡ç¨‹ã€‚ä¸Šé¢è¿™ä¸ªæç®€çš„åå‘ä¼ æ’­ç®—æ³•ç»™æˆ‘ä»¬ä¸€ä¸ªå¯ç¤ºï¼šä¸€ä¸ªç½‘ç»œç»“æ„åªéœ€è¦æœ‰å‚æ•°å’Œè®¡ç®—èŠ‚ç‚¹çš„å‡½æ•°å³å¯è®¾è®¡å‡ºæ¥ï¼Œåœ¨æ‰§è¡Œä¸€é forward å‡½æ•°åè¾“å…¥æ•°æ®å³å¯å¾—åˆ°è¾“å‡ºå€¼ã€‚è€Œæˆ‘ä»¬æ—¥å¸¸ä½¿ç”¨çš„æ·±åº¦å­¦ä¹ æ¡†æ¶å®é™…ä¸Šæ˜¯åŸºäºè®¡ç®—å›¾æ¨¡å‹ï¼Œé€šè¿‡ä¸€ä¸ªä¸ªèŠ‚ç‚¹å¯¹è±¡å®Œæˆå±æ€§å­˜å‚¨ã€æ–¹æ³•è°ƒç”¨ï¼Œç›¸æ¯”è¿™ç§æ‰‹å†™ä¸€ä¸ªç»Ÿä¸€çš„ forward è€Œè¨€ï¼Œæ›´çµæ´»æ›´é«˜æ•ˆï¼Œä¹Ÿæ›´ç¬¦åˆå®é™…ä½¿ç”¨åœºæ™¯ã€‚

Summary

After the variables in the computation graph are initialized by init, the forward method is called on the result node to recursively calculate the values of each node on the path. The information propagates forward along the computation graph and finally gets the value of the result node. Afterwards, backward method is called on nodes that need updating to recursively calculate Jacobi matrix of each node on the path with respect to the result node, and information is propagated backwards.

If multiple nodes need to be updated, such as weight vector nodes and bias nodes, call the backward method on each of these nodes respectively. Since the Jacobi matrix values of intermediate nodes have been saved in the Jacobi attribute, it is not necessary to calculate repeatedly when calling its backward method multiple times on multiple nodes. This is the core content of back propagation, which implements the chain rule of differentiation, saves intermediate results, and thus exchanges time for space.

Gradient Descend

åŸºäºè®¡ç®—å›¾æˆ‘ä»¬é‡æ–°å®¡è§†ä¸€ä¸‹æ¢¯åº¦ä¸‹é™çš„è¿‡ç¨‹ã€‚æ¢¯åº¦ä¸‹é™å³è®©æŸå¤±å‡½æ•°çš„å€¼æ²¿ç€æ¢¯åº¦æ–¹å‘é€æ¸ä¸‹é™ï¼Œè€ŒæŸå¤±å‡½æ•°ä¸‹é™çš„è¿‡ç¨‹å°±æ˜¯è®©è¾“å…¥å‡½æ•°çš„å‚æ•°å˜åŒ–çš„è¿‡ç¨‹ï¼Œå¦‚ä½•è®©æŸä¸ªå‚æ•°å˜åŒ–ï¼Ÿé‚£å°±æ˜¯ç”¨æŸå¤±å‡½æ•°æ±‚å…³äºè¯¥å‚æ•°çš„å¯¼æ•°ï¼Œç„¶åå¦è¯¥å‚æ•°å€¼å‡å»å­¦ä¹ ç‡å’Œè¯¥å¯¼æ•°çš„ä¹˜ç§¯ã€‚

åœ¨è®¡ç®—å›¾ä¸­çš„è¿‡ç¨‹å…·ä½“æ˜¯è¿™æ ·çš„ï¼š

  1. åˆå§‹åŒ–ï¼ˆè°ƒç”¨ç³»ç»Ÿåˆå§‹åŒ–ï¼‰å„èŠ‚ç‚¹ä»¥åŠå¯¹ value èŠ‚ç‚¹èµ‹å€¼ï¼ˆæ‰‹åŠ¨ï¼‰ï¼Œäº¦å³ç¡®å®šåˆå§‹å‚æ•°å’Œå–‚ç¬¬ä¸€ç»„æ•°æ®
  2. è°ƒç”¨ forward æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œè®¡ç®—æœ€ç»ˆè¦è¾“å‡ºçš„ç»“æœèŠ‚ç‚¹çš„å€¼
  3. åœ¨æ‰€æœ‰ trainable çš„èŠ‚ç‚¹ä¸Šè°ƒç”¨ backward æ–¹æ³•
  4. è°ƒç”¨ backward æ–¹æ³•åï¼Œå˜é‡èŠ‚ç‚¹çš„ Jacobi çŸ©é˜µå±æ€§ä¿å­˜äº†ç»“æœèŠ‚ç‚¹å¯¹å®ƒçš„æ¢¯åº¦çš„è½¬ç§©ï¼Œç”¨äºæ›´æ–°å‚æ•°
  5. æ¸…æ¥šèŠ‚ç‚¹å€¼ä»¥åŠ Jacobi çŸ©é˜µå€¼ï¼Œé‡æ–°å–‚æ–°æ•°æ®ï¼Œä»ç¬¬ 2 æ­¥é‡å¤æ‰§è¡Œ

å¹¶ä¸æ˜¯æ¯æ¬¡æ›´æ–°å‚æ•°éƒ½èƒ½ä¿è¯æŸå¤±å‡½æ•°åœ¨ä»»æ„æ•°æ®ä¸Šéƒ½æœç€å‡½æ•°å€¼ä¸‹é™çš„æ–¹å‘å‘å±•ï¼Œä½†é€šå¸¸ç»è¿‡æ•´ä¸ª epoch æ¥çœ‹ï¼Œè¿˜æ˜¯ä¼šå¯¹é™ä½æ¨¡å‹åœ¨å…¨ä½“è®­ç»ƒæ ·æœ¬ä¸Šçš„æŸå¤±å€¼æœ‰é‡è¦ä½œç”¨ã€‚ä¹‹æ‰€ä»¥ç”¨ä¸€ä¸ªæˆ–è€…éƒ¨åˆ†æ•°æ®è®¡ç®—å‡ºçš„æ¢¯åº¦å¯ä»¥æ›´æ–°åˆ°å‚æ•°ä¸Šï¼ŒåŸºäºçš„å°±æ˜¯éšæœºæ¢¯åº¦ä¸‹é™æ³• SGD çš„åŸç†ï¼ˆä¸€ä¸ªæ•°æ®è®¡ç®—æ¢¯åº¦å¯¹åº” SGD ç®—æ³•ï¼Œä¸€å°æ‰¹æ•°æ®è®¡ç®—æ¢¯åº¦å¯¹åº” Minibatch Gradient Descentï¼‰ã€‚

éšæœºæ¢¯åº¦ä¸‹é™æ³•

åœ¨ SGD è¿‡ç¨‹ä¸­æˆ‘ä»¬è¿˜è¦è€ƒè™‘ä¸€ä¸ªå‚æ•°éšæœºåˆå§‹åŒ–çš„é—®é¢˜ï¼Œæ·±åº¦å­¦ä¹ ä¸­çš„å‚æ•°åˆå§‹åŒ–æ˜¯æŒ‡å°†ç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œçš„æƒé‡å’Œåç½®åˆå§‹åŒ–ä¸ºç‰¹å®šçš„å€¼ã€‚è¿™äº›åˆå§‹å€¼å¯¹ç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œçš„è®­ç»ƒè¿‡ç¨‹æœ‰å¾ˆå¤§çš„å½±å“ï¼Œå› æ­¤é€‰æ‹©åˆé€‚çš„å‚æ•°åˆå§‹åŒ–æ–¹æ³•éå¸¸é‡è¦ã€‚

æ¨¡å‹çš„åˆå§‹å‚æ•°è®¾ç½®å¹¶ä¸æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªä¸ªæ‰‹åŠ¨èµ‹å€¼ï¼Œä¸€èˆ¬æ¥è¯´ï¼Œå¯ä»¥é‡‡ç”¨éšæœºåˆå§‹åŒ–ã€é›¶åˆå§‹åŒ–ã€Xavier/Glorot åˆå§‹åŒ–ã€Kaiming åˆå§‹åŒ–ä»¥åŠè‡ªå®šä¹‰åˆå§‹åŒ–äº”ç§æ–¹æ³•è¿›è¡Œå‚æ•°åˆå§‹åŒ–ã€‚å…¶ä¸­ï¼Œéšæœºåˆå§‹åŒ–æ˜¯æœ€å¸¸ç”¨çš„æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œå®ƒå°†æƒé‡éšæœºåœ°èµ‹äºˆä¸€ä¸ªæ¥è¿‘0çš„å°æ•°å€¼ï¼›è€Œé›¶åˆ™æ˜¯å°†æ‰€æœ‰æƒé‡éƒ½è®¾ä¸º0ï¼›Xavier/Glorot å’Œ Kaiming åˆ™æ˜¯å¯¹éšæœºåˆå§‹åŒ–è¿›è¡Œä¼˜åŒ–ï¼›è‡ªå®šä¹‰åˆ™æ˜¯æ ¹æ®ä¸åŒä»»åŠ¡é€‰æ‹©ä¸åŒçš„å‚æ•°æ¥èµ·ä½œç”¨ã€‚

å…³äºæ¢¯åº¦çš„è®¡ç®—æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œå®é™…å¸¸ç”¨é›…å¯æ¯”çŸ©é˜µï¼Œå‰é¢å·²ç»æåˆ°äº†é›…å¯æ¯”çŸ©é˜µçš„ç›¸å…³çŸ¥è¯†ï¼Œè¯¦ç»†çš„ Jacobi çŸ©é˜µæ•°å­¦çŸ¥è¯†åé¢ä¼šæœ‰ç¯‡å¹…å•ç‹¬ä»‹ç»ã€‚

entry.title: Distributed Machine Learning 02
entry.content:
Basics of Distributed Machine Learning

ä¸»è¦ä»‹ç»åŸºäºåˆ†å¸ƒå¼ç¯å¢ƒç‰¹ç‚¹ä¸‹çš„æ ¸å¿ƒæŠ€æœ¯ä¸ ML é‡è¦æ–¹æ³•

    flowchart LRA(Distributed ML)-->A1(Parallelism)A1-->A11(Data Parallelism)A1-->A12(Model Parallelism)A1-->A13(Hybrid Parallelism)A-->A2(Parameter Sharing)A2-->A21(Shared-Nothing)A2-->A22(Shared-Memory)A-->A3(Synchronization)A3-->A31(Bulk Synchronous Protocol)A3-->A32(Asynchronous Protocol)A3-->A33(Stale Synchronous Protocol)A-->A4(Communication)A4-->A41(Lower Numerical Precision)A4-->A42(Communication Compression)

Anatomy of Distributed Machine Learning

Computing Parallelism

å…¶ä»–å¸¸ç”¨çš„é›†åˆæ“ä½œç¬¦å¦‚ä¸‹è¡¨æ‰€ç¤ºï¼š

Collective OperatorFunction
MP_BcastThe root rank (worker) broadcasts its local data to all other ranks (workers).
MP_ScatterThe root rank partitions its local data item and sends one portion to each rank independently.
MPI_GatherThe root rank collects all the data items from other ranks, yielding an array of data items
MPI_RedruceThe root rank collects all the data items from other ranks and sums them together
MPI_AllgatherInstead of gathering the data items on the root rank, MPI_Allgather gathers the data items on every rank
MPI_AllreduceSimilarly, all the ranks perform the reduce operation and obtain the sum of all data items
MPI_AllToAllSimilarly, all the ranks perform the reduce operation and obtain the sum of all data items
MPI_BarrierTo schedule different ranks, MPI_Barrier sets a barrier which is a synchronization point for all the ranks

é‡åŒ–è¿™å—æ„Ÿè§‰è¿˜æ˜¯æŒºæœ‰æ„æ€çš„ï¼Œæ¶‰åŠåˆ°ç¼–ç ä¹‹ç±»çš„çŸ¥è¯†ï¼Œä»¥å‰å¬å®¤å‹æè¿‡ï¼Œä»¥ä¸ºä»…ä»…æ˜¯èˆå¼ƒæ•°æ®ç²¾åº¦ï¼Œè¿˜å¯»æ€ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆè¦ä¸“é—¨æœ‰äººç ”ç©¶è¿™ä¸ªã€‚ç°åœ¨å‘ç°è¿™æœ¬ä¹¦é‡Œæåˆ°çš„é‡åŒ–æ–¹æ³•è¿˜æ˜¯æ¯”è¾ƒå¤æ‚å’Œä¸¥è°¨çš„ã€‚

Gradient Sparsification

æ¢¯åº¦ç¨€ç–åŒ–æ˜¯æŒ‡ï¼šé€šè¿‡åªå‘é€æ¢¯åº¦å‘é‡ä¸­çš„é‡è¦åˆ†é‡å¹¶ä¸¢å¼ƒä¸å¤ªé‡è¦çš„åˆ†é‡æ¥å¯¹æ¢¯åº¦å‘é‡è¿›è¡Œç¨€ç–åŒ–ã€‚æ¢¯åº¦ç¨€ç–åŒ–æœ‰å¤šå¤§çš„å¿…è¦æ€§å‘¢ï¼Ÿ

Lin et al. find that 99.9% of the gradient exchange in distributed SGD is redundant. They propose Deep Gradient Compression (DGC) to greatly reduce communication cost . To preserve accuracy during this compression, DGC employs four techniques: momentum correction, local gradient clipping, momentum factor masking, and warm-up training.

å¯¹äº nn.linear()ï¼Œæ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªçº¿æ€§å±‚ï¼Œå…¶ä½œç”¨æ˜¯å°†è¾“å…¥çš„ n ä¸ªæ•°æ®æŒ‰ç…§ weight å’Œ bias è®¡ç®—å¥½åè¾“å‡ºä¸ºæŒ‡å®šçš„ç‰¹å¾å€¼ã€‚

åœ¨åš one classification çš„æ—¶å€™ï¼Œè®­ç»ƒé›†å’Œæµ‹è¯•é›†çš„æ ·æœ¬åˆ†å¸ƒæ˜¯ä¸ä¸€æ ·çš„ï¼Œå°¤å…¶éœ€è¦æ³¨æ„è¿™ä¸€ç‚¹ã€‚

å…¶æ¬¡ï¼Œè¿˜æœ‰ loss_fn().item()ï¼Œ.item() è¡¨ç¤ºå–å‡ºå¼ é‡å…·ä½“ä½ç½®çš„å…ƒç´ å…ƒç´ å€¼ï¼Œè¿”å›çš„æ˜¯è¯¥ä½ç½®å…ƒç´ å€¼çš„é«˜ç²¾åº¦å€¼ï¼Œä¸€èˆ¬ç”¨åœ¨æ±‚ loss æˆ–è€… accuracy æ—¶ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨ .item()ï¼Œè¿™æ ·å†™çš„å¥½å¤„å¯ä»¥å‚è€ƒ PyTorch æœ‰å“ªäº›å‘/bug

æ¨¡å‹å­˜å‚¨ä¸è¯»å–

å¯ä»¥å°†è®­ç»ƒå¥½çš„æ¨¡å‹å­˜èµ·æ¥ä»¥ä¾¿åç»­æ¨ç†ä½¿ç”¨ï¼ŒåŠ è½½æ—¶ä½¿ç”¨çš„æ˜¯modelå¯¹è±¡çš„åŠ è½½çŠ¶æ€å­—å…¸çš„æ–¹æ³•

å¦‚æœä¸åœ¨æ„æ˜¾å­˜å¤§å°å’Œè®¡ç®—æ—¶é—´çš„è¯ï¼Œä»…ä»…ä½¿ç”¨ model.eval() å·²è¶³å¤Ÿå¾—åˆ°æ­£ç¡®çš„ validation/test çš„ç»“æœï¼›è€Œ with torch.no_grad() åˆ™æ˜¯æ›´è¿›ä¸€æ­¥åŠ é€Ÿå’ŒèŠ‚çœ gpu ç©ºé—´ï¼ˆå› ä¸ºä¸ç”¨è®¡ç®—å’Œå­˜å‚¨æ¢¯åº¦ï¼‰ï¼Œä»è€Œå¯ä»¥æ›´å¿«è®¡ç®—ï¼Œä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥è·‘æ›´å¤§çš„ batch æ¥æµ‹è¯•ã€‚

entry.title: MapReduce Paper Reading Note
entry.content:
Introduction

What is MapReduce

MapReduce is a programming model and an associated implementation for processing and generating large data sets. Users specify a map function that processes a key/value pair to generate a set of intermediate key/value pairs, and a reduce function that merges all intermediate values associated with the same intermediate key. Many real world tasks are expressible in this model, as shown in the paper.

Mapreduce æ˜¯ä¸€ç§ç”¨äºå¤„ç†å’Œç”Ÿæˆå¤§å‹æ•°æ®é›†çš„ç¼–ç¨‹æ¨¡å‹å’Œç›¸å…³å®ç°ï¼Œå…¶è®¡ç®—é‡‡ç”¨ä¸€ç»„è¾“å…¥é”®/å€¼å¯¹ï¼Œå¹¶äº§ç”Ÿä¸€ç»„è¾“å‡ºé”®/å€¼å¯¹ã€‚ç”±ç”¨æˆ·æŒ‡å®šä¸€ä¸ª map å‡½æ•°å¤„ç†é”®/å€¼å¯¹ä»¥ç”Ÿæˆä¸€ç»„ä¸­é—´é”®/å€¼å¯¹ï¼Œä»¥åŠä¸€ä¸ª reduce å‡½æ•°åˆå¹¶ä¸åŒä¸€ä¸­é—´é”®å…³è”çš„æ‰€æœ‰ä¸­é—´å€¼ã€‚ä¸­é—´å€¼é€šè¿‡è¿­ä»£å™¨æä¾›ç»™ç”¨æˆ·çš„ reduce å‡½æ•°ã€‚è¿™ä½¿æˆ‘ä»¬èƒ½å¤Ÿå¤„ç†å¤ªå¤§è€Œæ— æ³•æ”¾å…¥å†…å­˜çš„å€¼åˆ—è¡¨ã€‚MapReduce çš„ç»“æœæ˜¯ç”Ÿæˆä¸€ä¸ªæ•°æ®é›†åˆ setï¼Œæœ€ç®€å•çš„ä¾‹å­ WordCount ä¹Ÿæ˜¯å¾—åˆ°äº†æ¯ä¸ªè¯ä»¥åŠå…¶å¯¹åº”çš„è¯é¢‘è¿™æ ·çš„ pair set

What Does MapReduce Do

The run-time system è¿è¡Œæ—¶ç³»ç»Ÿè´Ÿè´£çš„å†…å®¹æœ‰ï¼š

åˆ’åˆ†ï¼štakes care of the details of partitioning the input data

è°ƒåº¦ï¼šscheduling the programâ€™s execution across a set of machines

å¤„ç†å¼‚å¸¸ä¸é€šä¿¡ï¼šhandling machine failures, and managing the required inter-machine communication

ç¬¬ä¸€ä¸ªï¼Œæ˜¯æä¾›ä¸€ä¸ªå•æœºè¿è¡Œçš„ MapReduce çš„åº“ï¼Œè¿™ä¸ªåº“åœ¨æ¥æ”¶åˆ° MapReduce ä»»åŠ¡ä¹‹åï¼Œä¼šåœ¨æœ¬åœ°æ‰§è¡Œå®Œæˆ map å’Œ reduce çš„ä»»åŠ¡ã€‚è¿™æ ·ï¼Œä½ å°±å¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡æ‹¿ä¸€ç‚¹å°æ•°æ®ï¼Œåœ¨æœ¬åœ°è°ƒè¯•ä½ çš„ MapReduce ä»»åŠ¡äº†ï¼Œæ— è®ºæ˜¯ debugger è¿˜æ˜¯æ‰“æ—¥å¿—ï¼Œéƒ½è¡Œå¾—é€šã€‚

ç¬¬ä¸‰ä¸ªï¼Œæ˜¯ MapReduce æ¡†æ¶é‡Œæä¾›äº†ä¸€ä¸ªè®¡æ•°å™¨ï¼ˆcounterï¼‰çš„æœºåˆ¶ã€‚ä½œä¸ºå¼€å‘è€…ï¼Œä½ å¯ä»¥è‡ªå·±å®šä¹‰å‡ ä¸ªè®¡æ•°å™¨ï¼Œç„¶ååœ¨ Map å’Œ Reduce çš„å‡½æ•°é‡Œå»è°ƒç”¨è¿™ä¸ªè®¡æ•°å™¨è¿›è¡Œè‡ªå¢ã€‚æ‰€æœ‰ map å’Œ reduce çš„è®¡æ•°å™¨éƒ½ä¼šæ±‡æ€»åˆ° master èŠ‚ç‚¹ä¸Šï¼Œé€šè¿‡ä¸Šé¢çš„ HTTP æœåŠ¡å™¨é‡Œå±•ç°å‡ºæ¥ã€‚æ¯”å¦‚ï¼Œä½ å°±å¯ä»¥åˆ©ç”¨è¿™ä¸ªè®¡æ•°å™¨ï¼Œå»ç»Ÿè®¡æœ‰å¤šå°‘è¾“å…¥æ—¥å¿—çš„æ ¼å¼å’Œé¢„æœŸçš„ä¸ä¸€æ ·ã€‚å¦‚æœæ¯”ä¾‹å¤ªé«˜ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆå¤šåŠä½ çš„ç¨‹åºå°±æœ‰ Bugï¼Œæ²¡æœ‰å…¼å®¹æ‰€æœ‰åˆæ³•çš„æ—¥å¿—ã€‚æ¯”å¦‚åœ¨ Hadoop é‡Œï¼Œé€šè¿‡ JobTracker å°±å¯ä»¥æŸ¥çœ‹ Task çš„æ‰§è¡Œæƒ…å†µ

Deficiency

ä¸»è¦æœ‰ä¸¤ä¸ªç¼ºé™·ï¼š

ç¬¬ä¸€ç‚¹ï¼šè¿˜æ²¡æœ‰ 100% åšåˆ°è®©ç”¨æˆ·æ„è¯†ä¸åˆ°â€œåˆ†å¸ƒå¼â€çš„å­˜åœ¨ï¼Œæ— è®ºæ˜¯ Combiner è¿˜æ˜¯ Partitionerï¼Œéƒ½æ˜¯è®©å¼€å‘è€…æ„è¯†åˆ°ï¼Œå®ƒé¢å¯¹çš„è¿˜æ˜¯åˆ†å¸ƒå¼çš„æ•°æ®å’Œåˆ†å¸ƒå¼çš„ç¨‹åºã€‚è¿™ä¸€ä¸ªé—®é¢˜åæ¥é€šè¿‡ SQL å¾—åˆ°è§£å†³ï¼Œç¼–ç¨‹ç•Œé¢æ›´å‹å¥½ã€‚

entry.title: Distributed Machine Learning 01
entry.content:
Introduction

Background

ä¸»è¦çªå‡ºMachine Learningçš„å¿…è¦æ€§ä»¥åŠåˆ†å¸ƒå¼çš„å¿…è¦æ€§

  flowchart TDA(Big Data)--Theory Support-->B(Machine Learning)C(Distributed)--Performance Support-->B

ç›‘ç£å­¦ä¹ ï¼ˆSupervised Machine Learningï¼‰ä¸‹ä½¿ç”¨å¤§æ•°æ®è¿›è¡Œè®­ç»ƒæ˜¯ä¸å¯é¿å…çš„ã€‚å¦‚æœè®­ç»ƒé›†æ•°æ®æœ‰é™ï¼Œå‡è®¾è®­ç»ƒé›†å’Œæµ‹è¯•é›†æ˜¯å¼‚æ„çš„ï¼ˆheterogeneousï¼‰ï¼Œé€šå¸¸åœ¨testæ—¶ä¸å¦‚åœ¨trainæ—¶çš„æ•ˆæœå¥½ï¼›å‡è®¾æ˜¯åŒæ„çš„ï¼ˆhomogeneousï¼‰ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆæ¯”è¾ƒå®¹æ˜“äº§ç”Ÿè¿‡æ‹Ÿåˆã€‚æ‰€ä»¥è¿˜æ˜¯å¾—å¢å¤§æ•°æ®é›†å»æå‡trainçš„æ•ˆæœã€‚

äºæ˜¯å¯ä»¥è®¤ä¸ºæ•°æ®æ˜¯MLçš„åŸºçŸ³ï¼Œä¸ºäº†æ•ˆæœå¥½å°±è¦Big Dataæ‰è¡Œï¼Œè€ŒBig Dataçš„å¤„ç†åˆè¦åˆ†å¸ƒå¼æ¥å¸®åŠ©è§£å†³ã€‚è¿™ä¹Ÿè‡ªç„¶è€Œç„¶å¼•å‡ºäº†Distributed MLè¿™ä¸ªé¢†åŸŸã€‚

æ•´ä½“ä¸Šåˆ†å¸ƒå¼æœºå™¨å­¦ä¹ æœ‰ä»¥ä¸‹ä¸‰ä¸ªæ­¥éª¤ï¼š

  1. è®¡ç®—ï¼šeach worker performs calculations over the local model parameter and data, producing some statistics such as gradients;
  2. èšåˆï¼šthe statistics are aggregated through some communication channel;
  3. æ›´æ–°ï¼šthe local model parameters are updated using aggregated statistics

Gradient Optimization

æ¢¯åº¦ä¸‹é™æ˜¯ä¸€ç§æœ€ä¼˜åŒ–æ‰‹æ®µï¼Œæœ‰ç›‘ç£çš„MLé—®é¢˜çš„ç›®æ ‡æ˜¯æ‰¾åˆ°æœ€å°åŒ–ç›®æ ‡å‡½æ•° fff çš„ Î¸\thetaÎ¸ å€¼:

argÂ minâ¡Î¸f(Î¸)=âˆ‘i=1NL(xi,yiâtrainingdataÂ ;Î¸âparameterâŸlossÂ +Â Î©(Î¸)âŸregularization(1)arg\space \min\limits_{\theta}{f(\theta)}= \sum^{N}_{i=1} \underbrace{L(\overbrace{x_i,y_i}^{training data}\space;\overbrace{\theta}^{parameter}}_{loss}\space + \space\underbrace{\Omega(\theta)}_{regularization}\tag{1}argÂ Î¸minâ€‹f(Î¸)=i=1âˆ‘Nâ€‹lossL(xiâ€‹,yiâ€‹â€‹trainingdataâ€‹Â ;Î¸parameterâ€‹â€‹Â +Â regularizationÎ©(Î¸)â€‹â€‹(1)

ä½¿ç”¨æ¢¯åº¦ä¸‹é™æ³•æ›´æ–°å‚æ•° Î¸\thetaÎ¸ éœ€è¦æ±‚å‡ºæ¢¯åº¦å‘é‡ï¼ˆgradient vectorï¼‰ï¼Œè¦æ³¨æ„æ¢¯åº¦æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªå‘é‡ï¼Œæ˜¯å‡½æ•°å˜åŒ–æœ€å¿«ï¼ˆsteepestï¼‰çš„åœ°æ–¹:

â–½f(Î¸)â‰¡g(Î¸)=[âˆ‚fâˆ‚Î¸1,âˆ‚fâˆ‚Î¸2,â‹¯âˆ‚fâˆ‚Î¸s]T(2)\bigtriangledown{f(\theta)}\equiv{g(\theta)}= \lbrack \frac{\partial f}{\partial \theta _{1}} ,\frac{\partial f}{\partial \theta _2},\cdots\frac{\partial f}{\partial \theta _s}\rbrack ^{T}\tag{2}â–½f(Î¸)â‰¡g(Î¸)=[âˆ‚Î¸1â€‹âˆ‚fâ€‹,âˆ‚Î¸2â€‹âˆ‚fâ€‹,â‹¯âˆ‚Î¸sâ€‹âˆ‚fâ€‹]T(2)

ä¸Šé¢å…¬å¼ä¸­çš„ä¸€é˜¶æ¢¯åº¦å‘é‡æ˜¯å‚ç›´äºå‡½æ•°fffçš„è¶…å¹³é¢çš„ã€‚åŒæ—¶ï¼Œåœ¨äºŒé˜¶æ¢¯åº¦çŸ©é˜µï¼ˆHessian Matrixï¼‰ä¸­å­˜åœ¨s2s^2s2ä¸ªäºŒé˜¶å¯¼æ•°ï¼š

â–½2f(Î¸)â‰¡H(Î¸)â‰¡(âˆ‚2fâˆ‚Î¸12â‹¯âˆ‚2fâˆ‚Î¸1âˆ‚Î¸sâ‹¯â‹¯âˆ‚2fâˆ‚Î¸sâˆ‚Î¸1â‹¯âˆ‚2fâˆ‚Î¸s2)(3)\bigtriangledown ^2{f}{(\theta)}\equiv {H(\theta)}\equiv\begin{pmatrix} \frac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial \theta _{1}^{2}} & \cdots & \frac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial \theta _{1} \partial \theta_{s}} \\\cdots & & \cdots \\\frac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial \theta _{s} \partial \theta_{1}}& \cdots & \frac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial \theta _{s}^{2}}\\\end{pmatrix}\tag{3}â–½2f(Î¸)â‰¡H(Î¸)â‰¡â€‹âˆ‚Î¸12â€‹âˆ‚2fâ€‹â‹¯âˆ‚Î¸sâ€‹âˆ‚Î¸1â€‹âˆ‚2fâ€‹â€‹â‹¯â‹¯â€‹âˆ‚Î¸1â€‹âˆ‚Î¸sâ€‹âˆ‚2fâ€‹â‹¯âˆ‚Î¸s2â€‹âˆ‚2fâ€‹â€‹â€‹(3)

è¶…å¹³é¢
è¶…å¹³é¢æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªNç»´ç©ºé—´ä¸­çš„N-1ç»´å‡ ä½•å¯¹è±¡ï¼Œå®ƒç”±ä¸€ç»„N-1ç»´çš„å‘é‡å’Œä½ç§»é‡æ„æˆã€‚æ¯”å¦‚ï¼Œåœ¨3ç»´ç©ºé—´ä¸­ï¼Œè¶…å¹³é¢å°±æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ª2ç»´çš„å¹³é¢ï¼Œç”±ä¸‰ä¸ªå‘é‡å’Œä½ç§»é‡æ„æˆã€‚

æ±‚å¾—æ¢¯åº¦ç›®çš„æ˜¯ä¸ºäº†æ›´æ–°å‚æ•°ï¼Œä»¥ä¸€é˜¶æ¢¯åº¦ä¸ºä¾‹ï¼š

Î¸t+1=Î¸tâˆ’Î·fâ€²(Î¸t)(4)\theta_{t+1} = \theta_{t} - \eta f^{'}{(\theta_{t})} \tag{4}Î¸t+1â€‹=Î¸tâ€‹âˆ’Î·fâ€²(Î¸tâ€‹)(4)

MethodDetail
Steepest descent methodä½¿ç”¨ä¸€é˜¶æ¢¯åº¦æ›´æ–°å‚æ•°

Steepest Descent Method

æœ€é€Ÿä¸‹é™æ³•æ˜¯æœ€ç®€å•ä½†ä¹Ÿæ˜¯æœ€å¸¸ç”¨çš„ï¼Œå°¤å…¶æ˜¯å…¶å¼€é”€æ¯”è¾ƒå°ï¼Œå…¶ä»–çš„æ–¹æ³•åœ¨è®¡ç®—ã€å†…å­˜å ç”¨å’Œé€šä¿¡æ–¹é¢æ•ˆç‡ä½ä¸‹ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥åˆ†å¸ƒå¼MLä¸­ä¸€èˆ¬å…³æ³¨æœºå™¨å­¦ä¹ ä¸­çš„ä¸€é˜¶æ¢¯åº¦ä¼˜åŒ–

g(Î¸)â‰¡fâ€²(Î¸)â‰¡â–½f(Î¸)(5)g(\theta) \equiv f'(\theta) \equiv \bigtriangledown f{(\theta)}\tag{5}g(Î¸)â‰¡fâ€²(Î¸)â‰¡â–½f(Î¸)(5)

Conjugate Gradient Algorithm

å…±è½­æ¢¯åº¦æ³•æ˜¯ä¸€ç§è¿­ä»£æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œç”¨äºæ±‚è§£æœ€ä¼˜åŒ–é—®é¢˜ä¸­çš„æœ€å°å€¼ï¼Œæ˜¯æ±‚è§£ç¨€ç–å¯¹ç§°æ­£å®šçº¿æ€§æ–¹ç¨‹ç»„çš„æœ€æµè¡Œå’Œæœ€è‘—åçš„è¿­ä»£æŠ€æœ¯ä¹‹ä¸€ã€‚

å…±è½­æ¢¯åº¦æ³•é€šè¿‡åœ¨å½“å‰æ­¥éª¤è®¡ç®—å‡ºä¸€ä¸ªæ–°çš„æœç´¢æ–¹å‘ï¼Œä¸ä¸Šä¸€æ­¥çš„æœç´¢æ–¹å‘ç›¸åï¼Œæ¥æœ‰æ•ˆåœ°å¯»æ‰¾æœ€ä¼˜å€¼ã€‚å¯ä»¥ç”¨æ¥æ±‚è§£å‡¸ä¼˜åŒ–é—®é¢˜å’Œéå‡¸ä¼˜åŒ–é—®é¢˜ã€‚

è®¡ç®—ç¬¬tè½®çš„å…±è½­æ¢¯åº¦ä¸ºï¼š

pt+1=Î±tptâˆ’g(Î¸t)(6-1)p_{t+1} = \alpha_{t}p_{t}-g(\theta_{t})\tag{6-1}pt+1â€‹=Î±tâ€‹ptâ€‹âˆ’g(Î¸tâ€‹)(6-1)

Î±=g(Î¸k)Tg(Î¸k)g(Î¸kâˆ’1)Tg(Î¸kâˆ’1)(6-2)\alpha = \frac{g(\theta_k)^{T}g(\theta_k)}{g(\theta_{k-1})^{T}g(\theta_{k-1})}\tag{6-2}Î±=g(Î¸kâˆ’1â€‹)Tg(Î¸kâˆ’1â€‹)g(Î¸kâ€‹)Tg(Î¸kâ€‹)â€‹(6-2)

Newton Method

ä»å‡ ä½•ä¸Šè¯´ï¼Œç‰›é¡¿æ³•å°±æ˜¯ç”¨ä¸€ä¸ªäºŒæ¬¡æ›²é¢å»æ‹Ÿåˆä½ å½“å‰æ‰€å¤„ä½ç½®çš„å±€éƒ¨æ›²é¢ï¼Œè€Œæ¢¯åº¦ä¸‹é™æ³•æ˜¯ç”¨ä¸€ä¸ªå¹³é¢å»æ‹Ÿåˆå½“å‰çš„å±€éƒ¨æ›²é¢ï¼Œé€šå¸¸æƒ…å†µä¸‹ï¼ŒäºŒæ¬¡æ›²é¢çš„æ‹Ÿåˆä¼šæ¯”å¹³é¢æ›´å¥½ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥ç‰›é¡¿æ³•é€‰æ‹©çš„ä¸‹é™è·¯å¾„ä¼šæ›´ç¬¦åˆçœŸå®çš„æœ€ä¼˜ä¸‹é™è·¯å¾„ã€‚

å¯ä»¥ç”¨æ³°å‹’å±•å¼€åˆ°äºŒé˜¶æ¥è§£é‡Šç‰›é¡¿æ³•ï¼š

f(Î¸+Î´)â‰ˆf(Î¸)+g(Î¸)TÎ´+12Î´TH(Î¸)Î´(7)f(\theta + \delta) \approx f(\theta) + g(\theta)^{T}\delta+ \frac{1}{2} \delta^{T}H(\theta)\delta \tag{7}f(Î¸+Î´)â‰ˆf(Î¸)+g(Î¸)TÎ´+21â€‹Î´TH(Î¸)Î´(7)

å…¶ä¸­H(Î¸)H(\theta)H(Î¸)ä¸ºHessiançŸ©é˜µï¼Œå‡½æ•°å¢é‡è¿‘ä¼¼ä¸ºï¼š

f(Î¸+Î´)âˆ’f(Î¸)=g(Î¸)TÎ´+12Î´TH(Î¸)Î´(8)f(\theta + \delta) - f(\theta) = g(\theta)^{T}\delta+ \frac{1}{2} \delta^{T}H(\theta)\delta \tag{8}f(Î¸+Î´)âˆ’f(Î¸)=g(Î¸)TÎ´+21â€‹Î´TH(Î¸)Î´(8)

æ±‚å¯¼è§£å¾—å¢é‡æœ€å°æ—¶ï¼š

Î´=âˆ’H(Î¸)âˆ’1g(Î¸)(9)\delta = -H(\theta)^{-1}g(\theta)\tag{9}Î´=âˆ’H(Î¸)âˆ’1g(Î¸)(9)

æ€»çš„æ¥è¯´ï¼Œç‰›é¡¿æ³•ä¼˜ç¼ºç‚¹å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼š

  • ä¼˜ç‚¹ï¼šäºŒé˜¶æ”¶æ•›ï¼Œæ”¶æ•›é€Ÿåº¦å¿«

  • ç¼ºç‚¹ï¼šç‰›é¡¿æ³•æ¯ä¸€æ­¥éƒ½è¦æ±‚ç›®æ ‡å‡½æ•°çš„HessiançŸ©é˜µçš„é€†çŸ©é˜µï¼Œè®¡ç®—æ¯”è¾ƒå¤æ‚

Quasi-Newton Method

æ‹Ÿç‰›é¡¿æ³•æ˜¯åœ¨ä¸€é˜¶æ¢¯åº¦ä¸‹é™å’ŒäºŒé˜¶æ¢¯åº¦ä¸‹é™ä¹‹é—´çš„ä¸€ä¸ªtrade-offï¼Œæ‹Ÿç‰›é¡¿æ–¹æ³•æå‡ºä½¿ç”¨å…ˆå‰çš„ä¸€é˜¶æ¢¯åº¦æ¥è¿‘ä¼¼Hessian Matrixï¼Œä¸€å®šç¨‹åº¦ä¸Šé™ä½äº†è®¡ç®—é‡

First Order Gradient Optimization Algorithm

ä¸»è¦æœ‰ä¸‰ç§å¸¸è§æ‰‹æ®µï¼šæ‰¹é‡æ¢¯åº¦ä¸‹é™ã€éšæœºæ¢¯åº¦ä¸‹é™ï¼ˆSGDï¼‰ã€å°æ‰¹é‡æ¢¯åº¦ä¸‹é™

Batch Gradient Descent

Sequence Point

A sequence point is a point in program execution at which all side effects are evaluated before going on to the next step. In C, theÂ semicolonï¼ˆåˆ†å·ï¼‰Â in a statement marks a sequence point. ä½†å¹¶ä¸æ˜¯éå¾—æŒ‰ç…§åˆ†å·åƒµç¡¬åœ°åˆ¤å®šï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚å£°æ˜int a[10], b[20];ï¼Œåœ¨a[10]æœ«å°¾æ˜¯Sequence Pointï¼Œåœ¨b[20]æœ«å°¾ä¹Ÿæ˜¯ã€‚Cæ ‡å‡†è§„å®šä»£ç æ‰§è¡Œè¿‡ç¨‹ä¸­çš„æŸäº›æ—¶åˆ»æ˜¯Sequence Point,å½“åˆ°è¾¾ä¸€ä¸ªSequence Pointæ—¶,åœ¨æ­¤ä¹‹å‰çš„Side Effectå¿…é¡»å…¨éƒ¨ä½œç”¨å®Œæ¯•,åœ¨æ­¤ä¹‹åçš„Side Effectå¿…é¡»ä¸€ä¸ªéƒ½æ²¡å‘ç”Ÿã€‚è‡³äºä¸¤ä¸ªSequence Pointä¹‹é—´çš„å¤šä¸ªSide Effectå“ªä¸ªå…ˆå‘ç”Ÿå“ªä¸ªåå‘ç”Ÿåˆ™æ²¡æœ‰è§„å®šï¼Œç¼–è¯‘å™¨å¯ä»¥ä»»æ„é€‰æ‹©å„Side Effectçš„ä½œç”¨é¡ºåºã€‚
